Qualification for this preferred status is conditioned on the organization falling precisely within the terms of the statutory definition of an exempt organization.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|1|31:1">
<para.text>
<cc>Sun-Herald Corporation v. Duggan, 73 F.2d 298 (C.C.A. 2d Cir. 1934)</cc>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|1|31:1">
<para.text>
See <x>&dblsect;31:9 et seq.</x>
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> As a general rule, statutes granting exemptions are strictly construed against the taxpayer, who has the burden of showing he or she is within the exemption.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|1|31:1">
<para.text>
<cc>Canton Human Services Initiatives, Inc. v. Town of Canton, 4 Misc. 3d 413, 780 N.Y.S.2d 714 (Sup 2004)</cc>, citing <cc>Symphony Space, Inc. v. Tishelman, 60 N.Y.2d 33, 466 N.Y.S.2d 677, 453 N.E.2d 1094 (1983)</cc>; <cc>New York Trust Co. v. U.S., 63 Ct. Cl. 100, 1927 WL 2914 (1927)</cc>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Some courts consider charitable organizations an exception, however, and are inclined to grant exemption to any organization complying with the spirit and purpose of the exemption.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|1|31:1">
<para.text>
See, for example, <cc>Enterprise Ry. Equipment Co. v. U.S., 142 Ct. Cl. 192, 161 F. Supp. 590 (1958)</cc>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|1|31:1">
<para.text>
Exemption is thus crucial for successful fundraising activities, as well as successful operations. Tax considerations will inevitably play a major role in the organization and operation of any corporation or association of a charitable nature. Many of the forms and much of the legal discussion in this chapter reflect tax considerations.
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:2</designator>
<name>Charity and charitable organization defined</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Charities &key;1</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|2|31:2">
<para.text>
The term “charity” is used in a popular sense to mean any act of kindness to another. In a legal sense, a “charity” is a gift that tends to promote the well-doing and well-being of society, generally.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|2|31:2">
<para.text>
A list of the purposes for which a charitable (nonprofit) corporation may be formed is contained in <st>N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corp. Law &sect;201</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|2|31:2">
<para.text>
 <cc>Bob Jones University v. U.S., 461 U.S. 574, 103 S. Ct. 2017, 76 L. Ed. 2d 157, 10 Ed. Law Rep. 918 (1983)</cc>; <cc>Abrams v. Richmond County S.P.C., 125 Misc. 2d 530, 479 N.Y.S.2d 624 (Sup 1984)</cc>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|2|31:2">
<para.text>
For checklist of matters to be included in certificate of incorporation of nonprofit corporation for charitable purposes, see <x>&sect;31:25</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Definition of charity, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Charities &sect;1</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Meaning of charity, <rc>Am. Jur. 2d, Charities &dblsect;1, 2</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> For purposes of this chapter, however, “charity” or “charitable organization” will be used in a special sense to designate those organizations exempt from federal taxation under <st>Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code</st>.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|2|31:2">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|2|31:2">
<para.text>
For a list of additional organizations exempt from federal income taxation, see <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|2|31:2">
<para.text>
As to a charity's exemption from various state taxes and from federal income tax, generally, see <x>&dblsect;31:9 et seq.</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text><rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA), &dblpara;D-4000 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Tax-exempt organizations, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:53 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Included in such exempt status are corporations and other organizations organized and operated exclusively for religious, charitable, scientific, testing for public safety, literary or educational purposes; to foster certain amateur sports competitions; or for the prevention of cruelty to animals or children, no part of the net earnings of which inure to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual, and no substantial part of the activities of which is the carrying on of propaganda or otherwise attempting to influence legislation except as otherwise provided by the Internal Revenue Code,
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|2|31:2">
<para.text>
See <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(h)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> and which does not participate in or intervene in any political campaign on behalf of any candidate for public office, including the publishing or distributing of statements.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|2|31:2">
<para.text>
In New York, an organization formed to carry out a charitable purpose is usually organized as a corporation, since an unincorporated association cannot take title to real estate or to a permanent fund. <cc>Mount v. Tuttle, 183 N.Y. 358, 76 N.E. 873 (1906)</cc>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|2|31:2">
<para.text>
 Certain testamentary dispositions to unincorporated organizations are permissible where the organization incorporates within a specified period, <st>N.Y. Est. Powers &amp; Trusts Law &sect;3-1.3(b)</st>, or where the disposition is for a charitable purpose and is subject to court supervision. <st>EPTL &sect;8-1.1</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|2|31:2">
<para.text>
Incorporation of a charitable organization is governed by the <st>Not-for-Profit Corporation Law</st>. See <st>N-PCL &dblsect;101 et seq.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|2|31:2">
<para.text>
An association must be organized and have an organizing instrument to qualify for the federal income tax exemption. See <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)-1</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|2|31:2">
<para.text>
As to certain unincorporated associations authorized by statute, see Social and Recreation Nonprofit Organizations <x>&dblsect;30:1 et seq.</x>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|2|31:2">
<para.text>
As to procedure and forms to incorporate charitable organizations, see <x>&dblsect;31:4 et seq.</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|2|31:2">
<para.text>
As to qualifying for exemption, see <x>&dblsect;31:9 et seq.</x>
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|2|31:2">
<para.text>
The term “charitable” is used in this definition in its generally accepted legal sense and includes relief of the poor and distressed or the underprivileged; advancement of religion, education, or science; erection or maintenance of public buildings, monuments, or works; lessening of the burdens of government; and promotion of social welfare by organizations designed to accomplish any of the above purposes or to lessen neighborhood tensions, eliminate prejudice and discrimination, defend human and civil rights secured by law, or to combat community deterioration and juvenile delinquency.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|2|31:2">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)-1(d)(2)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Liability of Nonprofit Corporation for Engaging in For-Profit Business Activities, 46 Am. Jur. Proof of Facts 3d 431</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:3</designator>
<name>Private foundation defined</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4063</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|3|31:3">
<para.text>
A “private foundation” is basically one that is not publicly supported. Most exempt entities are private foundations and are subject to various additional requirements not imposed on publicly supported organizations. The Code presumes that an exempt organization is also a private foundation unless it falls within one of the exemptions.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|3|31:3">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;508(b)</st>. Unless the organization notifies the IRS that it is not a private foundation, it is presumed to be one. The notification is not required of churches or any other organization with income of $5,000 or less.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
</research.reference.block>
Presumption that exempt organization is private foundation, <field>rc.ref.id="I09H10P"</field><trace>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA)</trace>, &para;D-7200.
Presumption that exempt organization is private foundation, <field>rc.ref.id="I09H10P"</field><trace>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA)</trace>, &para;D-7200.
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|3|31:3">
<para.text>
The first exemption covers the “50 percent” charities listed in the charitable donations section of the Tax Code: churches, schools, hospitals, and publicly supported organizations.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|3|31:3">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;170(b)(1)(A)</st>. The name comes from the ability of a taxpayer to contribute up to 50% of income to these charities; contributions to other charities are limited to 30%.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Churches, schools, hospitals, etc., government supported charities and governmental units, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA), &para;D-7203</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private foundations defined, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:101</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Because the publicly supported criterion under the first exemption can be hazy, a second exemption offers a more specific test. If more than one-third of an organization's support comes from the public and not more than one-third comes from investment income, it is not a private foundation.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|3|31:3">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;509(a)(2)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Broadly supported organizations, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA), &dblpara;D-7204 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private foundations defined, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:101</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> However, the one-third support cannot come from a “disqualified person,” who is defined as one who is a substantial contributor to the organization, one who owns more than 20% of the stock, or one who manages the operation.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|3|31:3">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4946(a)</st>. Family members of these persons, along with trusts, partnerships, and corporations associated with them, are included as disqualified persons.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Disqualified persons with respect to private foundations, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA), &para;D-8100</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Disqualified person transactions, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:108 to 10:110</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> A “substantial contributor” is one who contributes more than $5,000 if that amount is more than 2% of the total contributions. If the organization is a trust, the creator of the trust is a substantial contributor even if his or her contribution is less than $5,000.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|3|31:3">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4946(a)(2)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Disqualified persons with respect to private foundations, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA), &para;D-8100</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Disqualified person transactions, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:108 to 10:110</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|3|31:3">
<para.text>
The remaining two exemptions are for organizations that operate on behalf of public charities and those engaged in testing for public safety.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|3|31:3">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;509(a)(3), (4)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|3|31:3">
<para.text>
Once an organization becomes a private foundation, it remains a private foundation until it becomes a public charity or distributes all assets to a public charity. It can also transfer assets to another private foundation but must then request that the termination tax not apply.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|3|31:3">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;507(g)(2)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Termination of private foundation status, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA), &dblpara;D-7228 to D-7231</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Termination of private foundation status, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:118</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
</section.block>
</analytical.level.body>
</analytical.level>
<analytical.level>
<front>
<outline.name.block>
<designator>B.</designator>
<name>Form Drafting Principles</name>
</outline.name.block>
</front>
<analytical.level.body>
<section.block>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:4</designator>
<name>Incorporation of charitable organizations</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3350 to 3499</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|4|31:4">
<para.text>
Under the New York Not-for-Profit Corporation Law
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|4|31:4">
<para.text>
<st>N-PCL &dblsect;101 et seq.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|4|31:4">
<para.text>
The New York Not-for-Profit Corporation Law applies to a domestic corporation or to a foreign corporation that conducts activities in New York State if the corporation is formed exclusively for purposes for which a not-for-profit corporation may be organized and if no part of the assets, income, or profits of which may be distributed to, or inure to the benefit of, its members, directors, or officers unless permitted by statute. <st>N-PCL &dblsect;102, 103</st>. Certain specified types of organizations formed under other statutes are excepted from the Law. <st>N-PCL &sect;103(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> (“Law”), one or more natural persons over the age of 18 may form a nonprofit corporation.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|4|31:4">
<para.text>
<st>N-PCL &sect;401</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Corporations may be formed under the Law either as a charitable corporation or a noncharitable corporation.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|4|31:4">
<para.text>
<st>N-PCL &sect;201(b)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|4|31:4">
<para.text>
Prior to its amendment by the Non-Profit Revitalization Act of 2013, the Law provided for four types of not-for-profit corporations, Types A, B, C and D. These four types were replaced with two types, charitable and noncharitable. Any corporation formed for both charitable purposes and noncharitable purposes will be deemed a charitable corporation for purposes of the Law. A type A not-for-profit corporation formed prior to July 1, 2014 will be deemed a noncharitable corporation under the Law. A Type B or C not-for-profit corporation will be deemed a charitable corporation. A Type D corporation formed for charitable purposes will be a charitable corporation and any other Type D corporation will be deemed a noncharitable corporation. <st>N-PCL &sect;201.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> This chapter discusses corporations categorized as charitable corporations.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|4|31:4">
<para.text>
For further discussion, see Social and Recreation Nonprofit Organizations <x>&dblsect;30:1 et seq.</x>
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|4|31:4">
<para.text>
The Law specifies the powers of nonprofit corporations,
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|4|31:4">
<para.text>
<st>N-PCL &sect;202</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Powers and functions of corporations, generally, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;421</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> which include the power to acquire, own, sell, and invest its funds in real and personal property for its use and benefit.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|4|31:4">
<para.text>
<st>N-PCL &dblsect;202(a)(4) to (6), 1307</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|4|31:4">
<para.text>
See also <st>N-PCL &sect;203</st> (corporation may have to obtain court approval to convey its property).
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|4|31:4">
<para.text>
The corporation may convey property to a member for a dwelling house. <st>N-PCL &sect;205</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Any corporation that is a private foundation
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|4|31:4">
<para.text>
For definition and discussion of private foundation, see <x>&sect;31:3</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> has specific restrictions on its powers.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|4|31:4">
<para.text>
<st>EPTL &sect;8-1.8</st>; <st>N-PCL &sect;406</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Specific requirements of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, see <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;71</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|4|31:4">
<para.text>
A nonprofit corporation may only conduct a business for profit as an incident to its primary purpose.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|4|31:4">
<para.text>
<st>N-PCL &sect;204</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Purposes of not-for-profit corporations, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;57, 58</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> However, such activity may undermine an attempt to qualify as a tax-exempt organization1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>10</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|4|31:4">
<para.text>
For discussion of qualifying for exemption, see <x>&sect;31:10</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> or subject it to unrelated business income tax.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>11</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|4|31:4">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;511</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|4|31:4">
<para.text>
As to taxation of unrelated business income, see <x>&sect;31:14</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:5</designator>
<name>Incorporation of charitable organizations<sep/> Formal requirements</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3374</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
To be accepted for filing by the Department of State, the certificate of incorporation must contain certain basic statements.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
<st>N-PCL &sect;402(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
For contents of the certificate, see <x>&sect;31:25</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Specific requirements of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, see <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;71</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The certificate must be in English, except that the corporate name may be in another language if written in English letters or characters.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
<st>N-PCL &sect;104(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Specific requirements of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, see <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;71</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The incorporators are required to comply with certain formalities as to the signing and filing of the certificate of incorporation. The certificate must be signed by each incorporator, with each incorporator's name and address included in the certificate.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
<st>N-PCL &sect;402(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The completed certificate must be delivered to the Department of State, together with any filing fees.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
<st>N-PCL &sect;402(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
For a listing of filing fees, see <st>N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corp. Law &sect;104-A</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Specific requirements of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, see <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;71</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
If the certificate is for the incorporation of an existing unincorporated association, an affidavit of the subscribers of the certificate must be attached to the certificate stating that they constitute a majority of the members of a committee duly authorized to incorporate the association.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
<st>N-PCL &sect;402(b)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Specific requirements of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, see <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;71</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
Provisions regarding the particular authority that gives approvals and consents that are required to appear on certificates of incorporation for not-for-profit corporations vary according to the purpose of the corporation and are set forth by statute.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
See <st>N-PCL &sect;404(a) to (v)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Specific requirements of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, see <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;71</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Not-for-profit corporations requiring administrative approval of certificate, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;77</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
In drafting the purpose clause for the certificate of incorporation, care should be taken to insure that this clause is sufficiently specific to qualify the corporation for exemption from federal income taxation.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
The certificate of incorporation of a corporation that is a private foundation is deemed to include restrictions on the corporation's right to do any of the acts that may result in excise taxes being imposed on the corporation. <st>N-PCL &sect;406(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Specific requirements of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, see <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;71</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Conditions imposed by statute upon exercise of powers; limitation on activities, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;423</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Purposes of not-for-profit corporations, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;57, 58</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
The completed certificate must be delivered to the Department of State.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
<st>N-PCL &sect;402(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Specific requirements of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, see <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;71</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Corporate existence begins upon the filing of the certificate of incorporation by that Department.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
<st>N-PCL &sect;403</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Effective date of certificate; effect of filing, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;81, 82</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The corporation has perpetual existence unless otherwise specified in the certificate.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>10</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
<st>N-PCL &sect;202(a)(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Duration, generally, see <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;110</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The certificate is conclusive evidence that all conditions precedent have been fulfilled and that the corporation has been formed as a not-for-profit corporation, except in an action or special proceeding brought by the Attorney General.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>11</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
<st>N-PCL &sect;403</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Effect of filing, see <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;81, 82</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
Securities issued by a not-for-profit corporation organized exclusively for charitable purposes are exempt from both federal and state securities registration statutes.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>12</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|5|31:5">
<para.text>
<st>15 U.S.C.A. &sect;77c(a)(4)</st>; <st>GBL &sect;359-f(e)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
</section.block>
</analytical.level.body>
</analytical.level>
<analytical.level>
<front>
<outline.name.block>
<designator>C.</designator>
<name>Requirements as to Registration of and Reporting by Charitable Organizations</name>
</outline.name.block>
</front>
<analytical.level.body>
<section.block>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:6</designator>
<name>Registration requirements for purposes of soliciting funds</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Charities &key;42</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6">
<para.text>
With several exceptions,
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6">
<para.text>
The most notable exceptions are:
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6">
<para.text>
(1) charitable organizations that do not intend to solicit and receive and do not actually receive contributions in excess of $25,000 during a fiscal year and that do not carry on any fundraising activities through professional fundraisers;
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6">
<para.text>
(2) charitable organizations that receive allocations from another organization that is in compliance with the registration requirements, that does not actually receive contributions in excess of $25,000 in excess of that allocation, and that does not use paid fundraisers; and
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6">
<para.text>
(3) any organization that receives substantially all of its funding from a single governmental agency and provides reports to that agency containing substantially the same information as required by the state registration statutes. For a complete list of exempt organizations, see <st>Exec. Law &sect;172-a</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> every charitable organization that intends to solicit contributions from persons in the state or from any governmental agency must file a prescribed registration form with the Attorney General before any solicitation.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6">
<para.text>
<st>Exec. Law &sect;172</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6">
<para.text>
A “charitable organization” for purposes of the filing requirement is any benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, or eleemosynary person or one purporting to be such or a law enforcement support organization. <st>Exec. Law &sect;171-a(1), (11)</st>. “Contribution” is the promise or grant of money or property of any kind or value, whether or not in combination with the sale of goods, services, entertainment, or any other thing of value (including a grant or other financial assistance from a government agency), except for payments by members of an organization in certain circumstances. <st>Exec. Law &sect;171-a(2)</st>. “Person” includes any individual, organization, group, association, partnership, corporation, or any combination of such entities. <st>Exec. Law &sect;171-a(3)</st>. “Solicit” means to directly or indirectly make a request for a contribution, whether express or implied, through any medium. <st>Exec. Law &sect;171-a(10)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6">
<para.text>
Professional fundraisers, commercial coventurers, and fundraising counsel are also required to register with the Attorney General. The mechanics of such registration are beyond the scope of this chapter. For statutory requirements, generally, see <st>Exec. Law &sect;173</st>. There is some indication that such requirements violate the registrant's constitutional right to free speech (see <cc>Riley v. National Federation of the Blind of North Carolina, Inc., 487 U.S. 781, 108 S. Ct. 2667, 101 L. Ed. 2d 669 (1988)</cc>). Such persons must file a copy of each contract with a charitable organization. <st>Exec. Law &sect;173-a(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Regulation of fundraising activities, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Charities &dblsect;83 to 93</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The information required in an application for registration is specified by statute.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6">
<para.text>
See <st>Exec. Law &sect;172(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6">
<para.text>
 For a checklist of matters to be included in an application for registration of solicitation, see <x>&sect;31:27</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Registration of charitable organizations, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Charities &sect;85</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Any statement filed must be signed under penalties of perjury by the President or other authorized officer and by the chief fiscal officer of the organization.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6">
<para.text>
See <st>Exec. Law &sect;172(2)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The fee for filing the statement is specified by statute.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6">
<para.text>
See <st>Exec. Law &sect;172(3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> A corporation that has properly registered pursuant to <st>Article 8 of the N.Y. Estates, Powers &amp; Trusts Law</st> is not required to register separately but must file with the Attorney General that it is registered under <st>Article 8</st> and provide all the additional documents (including any necessary additional financial filings) necessary to complete registration under the Executive Law.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6">
<para.text>
See <st>Exec. Law &sect;172(4)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Registration of charitable organizations, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Charities &sect;85</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> A registration remains in effect unless it is either canceled as provided by statute, withdrawn by the organization, or the organization has failed to file the required financial report and has not remedied that failure.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6">
<para.text>
See <st>Exec. Law &sect;172(5)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Registration of charitable organizations, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Charities &sect;85</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The President or other authorized officer of a charity must notify the Attorney General, under oath, within 30 days of any material change in any information required to be furnished in a registration statement.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6">
<para.text>
See <st>Exec. Law &sect;172(6)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Registration of charitable organizations, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Charities &sect;85</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6">
<para.text>
In addition to the registration requirements, registered charitable organizations generally must file an annual written financial report with the Attorney General on forms prescribed by that office.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6">
<para.text>
See <st>Exec. Law &sect;172-b</st>, specifying when the reports must be audited.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Annual reporting by charitable organizations, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Charities &sect;87 87 , except that where such records are forms including the names, addresses or telephone numbers of contributors and amounts contributed by them, such names, addresses, and telephone numbers of contributors and amounts contributed by them shall not be a public record and shall not be subject to disclosure pursuant to Article Six of the Public Officers Law, and the a ttorney g eneral shall keep such information confidential, except when authorized by a court order, and use it solely for the purpose of conducting investigations and litigation to enforce the not-for-profit corporation and religious corporation laws, the provisions of this article, A rticle E ight of the E states, P owers and T rusts L aw, and the attorney general's other authority to oversee charities and charitable assets.1<footnote><footnote.body></rc></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
<field><para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6"</field>See <st>Exec. Law &sect;172(8)</st>.
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6">
<para.text>
See <st>Exec. Law &sect;172(8)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Utilizing or exploiting registration to suggest an endorsement or approval by the state is prohibited.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>12</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|6|31:6">
<para.text>
See <st>Exec. Law &sect;172(9)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Registration of charitable organizations, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Charities &sect;85</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:7</designator>
<name>Checklist<sep/> Matters to include in an application for registration of solicitation</name>
</outline.name.block>
<online.view>
<online.view.item>COL</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>NFP</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>CHK</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>FCV</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>FTR</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>EBL</online.view.item>
</online.view>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<check.list>
<list list.style="para">
<list.item>
<name.block>
<designator>1</designator>
</name.block>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|7|31:7">
<para.text>Name of the organization and the name or names under which it intends to solicit contributions.</para.text>
</para>
</list.item>
<list.item>
<name.block>
<designator>2</designator>
</name.block>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|7|31:7">
<para.text>The names and business, residence, or other addresses where each can regularly be found of the officers, directors, trustees, and executive personnel of the organization.</para.text>
</para>
</list.item>
<list.item>
<name.block>
<designator>3</designator>
</name.block>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|7|31:7">
<para.text>Addresses of the organization, including addresses of any offices within the state. (If the organization does not maintain a principal office in New York, include the name and address of the person having custody of its financial records).</para.text>
</para>
</list.item>
<list.item>
<name.block>
<designator>4</designator>
</name.block>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|7|31:7">
<para.text>Statement as to where and when the organization was established, its form of organization, and its tax exempt status. The form must include a copy of the most recent letter of exemption, if any, issued by the Internal Revenue Service, the most recent communication from the Internal Revenue Service regarding any audit thereby, if any, and a copy of any organizational documents, such as the certificate of incorporation, bylaws, and amendments to those documents.</para.text>
</para>
</list.item>
<list.item>
<name.block>
<designator>5</designator>
</name.block>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|7|31:7">
<para.text>A clear description of the specific programs for which the solicited contributions will be used, and a statement as to whether those programs are in existence or planned.</para.text>
</para>
</list.item>
<list.item>
<name.block>
<designator>6</designator>
</name.block>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|7|31:7">
<para.text>Date on which the fiscal year of the organization ends.</para.text>
</para>
</list.item>
<list.item>
<name.block>
<designator>7</designator>
</name.block>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|7|31:7">
<para.text>Statement as to whether the organization is authorized by any other governmental authority to solicit contributions and whether it or any of its present officers, directors, executive personnel, or trustees are or have ever been fined or otherwise penalized or enjoined from soliciting contributions or have been found to have engaged in unlawful practices regarding solicitation of contributions or administration of charitable assets and whether its registration or license has been suspended or cancelled by any court or other governmental agency together with the identity of such courts or governmental agencies and the reasons for such fine, penalty, injunction, suspension, or cancellation.</para.text>
</para>
</list.item>
<list.item>
<name.block>
<designator>8</designator>
</name.block>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|7|31:7">
<para.text>Names and addresses of any professional fundraisers, fundraising counsel, or commercial coventurers who are acting or who have agreed to act on behalf of the organization.</para.text>
</para>
</list.item>
<list.item>
<name.block>
<designator>9</designator>
</name.block>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|7|31:7">
<para.text>A copy of the organization's annual report, if any, for the immediately preceding fiscal year.</para.text>
</para>
</list.item>
<list.item>
<name.block>
<designator>10</designator>
</name.block>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|7|31:7">
<para.text>The names and addresses of any chapters, branches, affiliates, or organizations that share in the contributions or other revenue received in the state.</para.text>
</para>
</list.item>
</list>
<note.block>
<note.group note.head="none">
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|7|31:7">
<para.text>
This checklist is based on <st>Exec. Law &sect;172(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</note.group>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Charities &key;42</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text><rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Charities &sect;85</rc></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</note.block>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:8</designator>
<name>Registration requirements for purposes of acting as holding or administering property or income</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Charities &key;41.5</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Charities &key;45</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Charities &key;48</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|8|31:8">
<para.text>
With certain exceptions,
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|8|31:8">
<para.text>
<st>EPTL &sect;8-1.4(b)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> every trustee must file with the Attorney General, within six months after any property held by the trustee or any income therefrom is required to be applied to charitable purposes, a copy of the instrument providing for the trustee's title, powers and duties.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|8|31:8">
<para.text>
<st>EPTL &sect;8-1.4(d)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Attorney General's supervisory powers under statutes pertaining to charitable trustees, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Charities &sect;79</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|8|31:8">
<para.text>
In addition, every trustee must, with certain exceptions,
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|8|31:8">
<para.text>
<st>EPTL &sect;8-1.4(b)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> file annual financial reports on forms prescribed by the Attorney General and under penalties for perjury, stating information as to the nature of assets held for charitable purposes and the administration of those assets. Every trustee is also required to file with the Attorney General and all identified current charitable beneficiaries a notice of the termination of the interest of any party in a trust that would cause all or part of the trust assets to be applied to charitable purposes or to have income therefrom so applied.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|8|31:8">
<para.text>
<st>EPTL &sect;8-1.4(f)(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Attorney General's supervisory powers under statutes pertaining to charitable trustees, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Charities &sect;79</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|8|31:8">
<para.text>
Trustees required to report to the Attorney General pursuant to <st>Article 7-A of the N.Y. Executive Law</st> must comply with the aforementioned annual financial reporting requirements by filing with the Attorney General, in addition to any other required reports, copies of any not-previously-filed financial reports required by <st>Exec. Law &sect;172-b</st>.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|8|31:8">
<para.text>
<st>EPTL &sect;8-1.4(f)(2)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Registration and reporting requirements of trustees, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Charities &sect;59</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|8|31:8">
<para.text>
Unless the filing of reports is suspended, the first report must be filed within six months after the end of the fiscal year during which the trustee becomes subject to the filing requirement.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|8|31:8">
<para.text>
<st>EPTL &sect;8-1.4(g)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Registration and reporting requirements of trustees, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Charities &sect;59</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|8|31:8">
<para.text>
There is a fee for filing the registration and reports.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|8|31:8">
<para.text>
See <st>EPTL &sect;8-14(p)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Registration and reporting requirements of trustees, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Charities &sect;59</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The registration, copies of instruments, and reports become open to public inspection. However, the Attorney General must withhold from public inspection copies of any report filed with any other governmental agency of New York or of the United States and required by law to be kept confidential by such agency and must, upon request of the trustee, withhold from public inspection that portion of any instrument filed that does not relate to charitable purposes and that is not otherwise of public record.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|8|31:8">
<para.text>
<st>EPTL &sect;8-1.4(l)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Registration and reporting requirements of trustees, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Charities &sect;59</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
</section.block>
</analytical.level.body>
</analytical.level>
<analytical.level>
<front>
<outline.name.block>
<designator>D.</designator>
<name>Tax Aspects</name>
</outline.name.block>
</front>
<analytical.level.body>
<analytical.level>
<front>
<outline.name.block>
<designator>1</designator>
<name> Qualification and Application for Tax Exemption</name>
</outline.name.block>
</front>
<analytical.level.body>
<section.block>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:9</designator>
<name>In general</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
Qualification for tax-exempt status under federal law is conditioned on the applicant's falling precisely within the terms of the statutory exemption in Section 501(c)(3)
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> of the Code.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
<cc>Sun-Herald Corporation v. Duggan, 73 F.2d 298 (C.C.A. 2d Cir. 1934)</cc>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
An organization operated for the primary purpose of carrying on a trade or business for profit is not exempt from taxation on the ground that all of its profits are payable to one or more organizations that are exempt from taxation. The term “trade or business” does not, however, include: (1) the deriving of rents from real property (and personal property leased with it), with certain exceptions; (2) any trade or business in which substantially all the work in carrying it on is performed for the organization without compensation; or (3) any trade or business which is the selling of merchandise, substantially all of which has been received by the organization as gifts or contributions. <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;502</st>. In determining the primary purpose of an organization, all of the circumstances must be considered, including the size and extent of the trade or business and the size and extent of those activities of such organization that are specified in the exemption statute. <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.502-1(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
 For a definition of organizations that qualify under <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(3)</st>, see <x>&sect;31:1</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>For discussion of exempt organizations, generally, see <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-4000 et seq., and Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:53 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
For federal income tax purposes, associations are generally treated as corporations as long as they possess sufficient corporate characteristics, such as limited liability, centralized management, free transferability of interests, and continuity of existence.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
See <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;301.7701-1(b)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
Notwithstanding the exemption from federal income taxation, generally, charitable corporations are required to file an annual information return on <st>IRS Form 990</st> and private foundations are required to file an annual information return on <st>IRS Form 990-PF</st>.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6033</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
Failure to file a return where required may result in the imposition of penalties. <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6652</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private foundation returns, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;S-2860 to S-2862</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
Although private foundations are generally exempt from income tax, they are subject to special taxes and to notification and reporting requirements.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
For a discussion of the taxes on private foundations, see <x>&sect;31:19</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
Subject to certain restrictions on contributions of appreciated property and other restrictions, contributions or gifts to exempt charitable organizations are currently deductible in computing federal income,
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;170</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> estate,
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;2055</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> and gift taxes.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;2522</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
The New York Constitution provides that the legislature may, by general law, which cannot be repealed, exempt from taxation the property used exclusively for religious, educational, or charitable purposes and owned by any corporation organized exclusively for one or more of such purposes and not operating for profit.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
<st>N.Y. Const. Art. XVI, &sect;1</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
For a discussion of this exemption, see <x>&sect;31:16</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Exemption from real-property taxation of residential facilities maintained by hospital for patients, staff, or others, 61 A.L.R.4th 1105</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Tax exemption of property of educational body as extending to property used by personnel as living quarters, 55 A.L.R.3d 485</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Taxation: exemption of parsonage or residence of minister, priest, rabbi, or other church personnel, 55 A.L.R.3d 356</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Prospective use for tax-exempt purposes as entitling property to tax exemption, 54 A.L.R.3d 9</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Receipt of pay from beneficiaries as affecting tax exemption of charitable institutions, 37 A.L.R.3d 1191</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Homes for the aged as exempt from property taxation, 37 A.L.R.3d 565</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:10</designator>
<name>Qualification for exemption from federal income taxation</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
To qualify for exemption from federal income taxation, an organization must establish that its purpose falls within one of the statutory categories
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Tax-exempt organizations, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:53 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> and that its activities demonstrably serve and are in harmony with the public interest.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<cc>Bob Jones University v. U.S., 461 U.S. 574, 103 S. Ct. 2017, 76 L. Ed. 2d 157, 10 Ed. Law Rep. 918 (1983)</cc> (the tax exemption may be denied if an otherwise qualified organization practices racial discrimination); <st>Rev. Rul. 71-447, 1971-2 C.B. 230.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The organization must be both organized and operated exclusively for charitable purposes.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Form of organization, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:54</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Exempt purposes, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:56</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
Organizational test. A charity is considered organized exclusively for one or more charitable purposes only when its articles of organization (certificate of incorporation, certificate of association, etc.) limit the purposes of the organization to one or more charitable purposes and do not expressly empower the organization to engage in substantial activities not in furtherance of its charitable purposes.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)-1(b)(1)(i), (2)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Form of organization, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:54</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> In meeting this test, the organization's purposes, as stated in its articles of organization, may be as broad as, or more specific than, the language contained in <st>Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code</st>, but in no event may they be broader.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)-1(b)(1)(ii), (iv).</st>
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> An organization is not organized exclusively for one or more exempt purposes if its articles expressly empower it to devote more than an insubstantial part of its activities to attempting to influence legislation by propaganda or otherwise or directly or indirectly to participate in or intervene in any political campaign on behalf of or in opposition to any candidate for public office, including the publishing or distributing of statements, or to have objectives and to engage in activities that characterize it as an “action” organization.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)-1(b)(3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Form of organization, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:54</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Exempt purposes, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:56</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
An organization is not organized exclusively for one or more exempt purposes unless its assets are dedicated to an exempt purpose. However, an organization does not meet the organizational test if, upon dissolution, its articles or the law of the state in which it was created provides that its assets would be distributed to its members or shareholders.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)-1(b)(4)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Form of organization, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:54</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<feature.para.block>
<name.block>
<name>Practice Tips:</name>
</name.block>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
To avoid any problem in obtaining the exemption, it is strongly recommended that the certificate of incorporation of all corporations seeking an exemption contain an express provision irrevocably dedicating the corporation's assets to charitable use and requiring that the assets be distributed to a corporation that will continue to use them for charitable purposes.
</para.text>
</para>
</feature.para.block>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
In construing the articles of organization, the law of the state of creation is controlling. However, any organization contending that any terms have, under state law, a different meaning from their generally accepted meaning must establish the special meaning by clear and convincing reference to relevant court decisions opinions of the state Attorney General, or to other evidence of applicable state law.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)-1(b)(5)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
Operational test. An organization will be regarded as operated exclusively for charitable purposes when it engages primarily in activities that accomplish one or more of the exempt purposes specified in <st>Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code</st> and if no more than an insubstantial portion of its activities is not in furtherance of such purposes.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)-1(c)(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10" date.trace="1">
<para.text>
An organization is not operated exclusively for one or more exempt purposes if its net earnings inure in whole or in part to the benefit of private shareholders or individuals.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>10</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)1(c)(2)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private inurement, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA)&dblpara;D-4040 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private benefit rules, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:88</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
Formerly, if an exempt organization violated the rules against private benefit, the Service's only option was to revoke its exempt status. There are now intermediate sanctions under Section 4958, which imposes excise taxes if a charitable organization transfers an excess benefit to a disqualified person.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>11</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4958</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Excise taxes on excess benefit transactions, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-6650 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
An “excess benefit transaction” is a transaction in which an economic benefit is provided by an exempt organization to a disqualified person in excess of the consideration received.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>12</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4958(c)(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Excise taxes on excess benefit transactions, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA)&dblpara;D-6650 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> A “disqualified person” is someone who, during the five years preceding the transaction, was in a position to exercise substantial influence over the affairs of the organization. Disqualified persons also include family members and certain entities in which at least 35% of the control or beneficial interest are held by persons described in the preceding sentence.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>13</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4958(f)(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Excise taxes on excess benefit transactions, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-6650 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
Initially, the person receiving the benefit must pay a tax of 25% of the amount of the excess benefit.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>14</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4958(a)(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> If not corrected within the prescribed period, the person must then pay a tax of 200% of the excess benefit.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>15</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4958(b)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> In addition, an organization manager who knowingly participates in the excess benefit transaction must pay a tax of 10% of the excess benefit.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>16</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4958(a)(2)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The maximum amount of this final tax is limited to $20,000.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>17</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4958(d)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Persons liable for these taxes must file a Form 4720.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>18</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
See <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;53.6011-1(b)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Excise taxes on excess benefit transactions, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-6650 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
Furthermore, “action” organizations, including organizations that have as a substantial part of their activities an attempt to influence legislation by propaganda or otherwise, organizations which participate or intervene, directly or indirectly, in any political campaign on behalf of or in opposition to any candidate for a public office if their main or primary objective or objectives may be attained only by legislation or a defeat of proposed legislation and if they advocate or campaign for the attainment of such main or primary objective or objectives as distinguished from engaging in nonpartisan analysis, study, or research, are not operated exclusively for exempt purposes within the meaning of <st>Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code</st>.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>19</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)-1(c)(3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Political activities, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:92</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> However, such an action organization may, nevertheless, qualify as a social welfare organization under Section 501(c)(4) if it meets the requirements therein.2
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>20</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
See <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(4)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
Additionally, in the case of an organization operated for the primary purpose of carrying on a trade or business for profit, exemption is not allowed under <st>Section 501 of the Internal Revenue Code</st> on the ground that all the profits of such organization are payable to one or more organizations exempt from taxation.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>21</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;502</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private inurement, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-4040 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private benefit rules, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:88</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:11</designator>
<name>Application for exemption from federal income taxation</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
A new charitable organization is not treated as exempt under Section 501(c)(3) unless and until it gives the IRS notice that it is applying for recognition of its exempt status.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;508(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Exempt organization status, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-7200</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The notice requirements do not apply to churches, to associations of churches, or to organizations (other than private foundations) with gross receipts not in excess of $5000.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;508(c)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>For a discussion of the application by a charitable organization for determination of exempt status, see <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA)&dblpara;D-4000 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
