<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Liability of Nonprofit Corporation for Engaging in For-Profit Business Activities, 46 Am. Jur. Proof of Facts 3d 431</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11" date.trace="1">
<para.text>
Notice is generally given by filing <st>IRS Form 1023 </st> within 15 months after the end of the month in which the organization was organized.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.508-1(a)(2)(i)</st> (also providing that any requests for extension of time for the filing of such notice be submitted to the <trace>appropriate office</trace>).
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
See also <cc>National Paralegal Inst. Coalition v. C.I.R., T.C. Memo. 2005-293, T.C.M. (RIA) P 2005-293 (2005)</cc>, where the Service reviews procedural aspects of filing Form 1023.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Application by a charitable organization for determination of exempt status, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-4000 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Application for exempt status, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:57</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
Any organization excepted from the requirement of filing notice under Section 508(a) will be exempt from taxation under Section 501(c)(3) if it meets the requirements of that section, whether or not it files such notice. However, in order to establish the exemption with the Internal Revenue Service and receive a ruling or determination letter recognizing its exempt status, an organization excepted from the notice requirement should file proof of its exemption.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.508-1(a)(4)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
Along with <st>IRS Form 1023</st>, the applicant must submit certain documents establishing conformity with organizational and operational requirements.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
For discussion of organizational and operational requirements for exemption, see <x>&sect;31:9</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
For a checklist of the documents that should accompany the application, see <x>&sect;31:28</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
When an organization has established its exempt status, the IRS will issue a ruling or determination letter. Such a ruling or determination letter may be issued in advance of operations if the organization can describe its proposed operations in sufficient detail to permit a conclusion that it will clearly meet the particular requirements of the section of law under which exemption is claimed.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
<st>I.R.S. Pub. 557.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Normally, such a determination is effective as of the date the organization was formed. However, if an organization is required to alter its activities or substantially amend its charter to qualify, the ruling or determination letter is effective as of the date specified in the letter.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
<st>I.R.S. Pub. 557</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> If a nonsubstantial amendment is made, such as correction of a clerical error in the enabling instrument or the addition of a dissolution clause, exemption is usually recognized as of the date of formation if the organization's activities before the ruling or determination are consistent with the exemption requirements.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
<st>I.R.S. Pub. 557.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Upon obtaining recognition of exemption, the organization may file a claim for a refund of income taxes paid for the period for which its exempt status is recognized.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>10</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
<st>I.R.S. Pub. 557.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
Rulings and determination letters granting exemptions may be revoked. The revocation may be retroactive if the organization omitted or misstated a material fact, operated in a manner materially different from that originally represented, or engaged in a prohibited transaction.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>11</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;601.201(n)(6)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Continuity of exemption, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-4002</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:12</designator>
<name>Effect of exempt status; returns</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
Unless it is also classified as a private foundation,
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
See <st>26 U.S.C.A. &dblsect;4940 et seq.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
For definition of private foundation, see <x>&sect;31:3</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> an organization that establishes its status as a charity is exempt from income tax, except with respect to unrelated business income.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
<st>NYTL &dblsect;290 et seq.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
As to taxation of unrelated business income, see <x>&sect;31:14</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Notwithstanding this exemption, most charities are required to file federal annual information returns.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6033</st> (<st>IRS Form 990</st>).
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
For exceptions to filing, see <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6033(a)(3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private foundation returns, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;S-2860 to S-2862</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Failure to file these returns may result in the imposition of penalties.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
See <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6652</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
The Code requires an exempt organization to allow public inspection of its application for exemption and its three most recent annual information returns. The exempt organization must furnish copies of these documents on request. The copies must be provided without charge, other than for the reasonable costs of copying and mailing.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
See <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6104(d)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Disclosure requirements, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:58</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
Private foundations also are required to allow public inspection of the entities' tax returns.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
See <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6104(d)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:13</designator>
<name>Tax differences among exempt organizations</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
The tax treatment of an exempt organization depends on the specific requirements imposed on the organization and which of the three basic classifications in which it is placed. Exempt organizations are initially divided between public charities and private foundations. Public charities include hospitals, schools, and churches. Private foundations are then divided between operating foundations and nonoperating foundations. In addition to these fundamental differences, the tax code imposes specific requirements on specific exempt entities. For example, a social club must not discriminate in membership qualifications on the basis of race, color, or religion in order to remain exempt.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(i)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Discriminatory actions of social clubs, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-6607</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Social and recreational clubs, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:75</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
Four basic categories of difference exist among the three basic forms of exempt organizations. For some purposes, private operating foundations are treated like public charities, while for other purposes they are treated like private foundations.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
Charitable deduction limitations. The limit on contributions to a public charity is the maximum amount allowed under the Code, which is 50% of the contributor's adjusted gross income for cash contributions and 30% for property that has appreciated in value.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;170(b)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Qualified donee charitable organizations, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA), &dblpara;K-2850 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Charitable contributions, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:74</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Deductible contributions, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:119 to 10:144</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The same limitation applies to private operating foundations. For private (nonoperating) foundations, the limit is 30% for both kinds of property. Certain other property is limited to 20% of income and the amount deducted is limited to the donor's basis in the property.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
Permitted activities. Of the three groups, a public charity is granted the most freedom as to its manner of operating. It either may operate its own activities or may make grants to other operating entities. It may also engage in lobbying activities. A private operating foundation must be at least partially engaged in operational activities in order to be a private operating foundation, while a private foundation only makes grants to others. Neither a private foundation nor a private operating foundation may engage in lobbying activities. A private foundation may not make grants in excess of stated amounts to other private foundations.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
Tax on entities. A public charity is not subject to tax on its activities except for a tax levied on the charity's unrelated business income
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;511(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> and a tax on excess lobbying expenditures.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4911(c)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
Taxation of unrelated business income, see <x>&sect;31:14</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
Both private foundations and private operating foundations are subject to a variety of taxes on disqualified transactions and on undistributed income. The tax starts at 2% initially and can then reach 200%. Disqualified activities include such things as self-dealing between the organization and its managers or contributors, excess investments in private corporations, jeopardy investments in general, and similar actions.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &dblsect;4940, 4941</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
For rules on self-dealing see, <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4941(d)</st>. Self-dealing involves certain acts by a disqualified person (see <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;53.4941(d)-1(a)</st>). A disqualified person is defined as a substantial contributor; a foundation manager; a person who owns more than 20% of a corporation, partnership, trust, or unincorporated enterprise which is itself a substantial contributor; and/or a member of the family of any individual of the first three categories. See <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4946(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
Distribution requirements. Public charities are not subject to any requirement as to distributions. However, an operating foundation must distribute at least 3 1/3% of the value of its investment assets, while a nonoperating foundation must distribute at least 5% of its assets.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4942</st>. An operating foundation need pay only two-thirds of its minimum return rather than the full amount required of a nonoperating foundation.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Tax on failure to distribute income, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-7700 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Distribution of income by private foundations, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:111, 10:112</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:14</designator>
<name>Taxation of unrelated business income</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
Under both state and federal law, charitable organizations are subject to a tax, comparable to an ordinary business tax at corporate rates, on unrelated business income.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;511</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
<st>NYTL &dblsect;290 et seq.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Unrelated business income, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-6800 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Income, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:59</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Dividends, interest, and royalties, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:68</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Other investment income, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:70</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Rents, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:71</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> An unrelated business is one, the conduct of which (aside from the need for funds) is not substantially related to the charitable function of the exempt organization.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;513</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
Exception is made for businesses in which all work is performed without compensation; in which the business is carried out primarily for the convenience of members, officers, employees, students, or patients; or in which the business consists of selling merchandise substantially all of which has been received as gifts or contributions. <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;513(a)(1) to (3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Unrelated trade or business defined, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-6800 to D-6804</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Income, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:59</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Interest, rents, royalties, and annuities received from certain controlled corporations are also subject to the tax on unrelated business income.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;512(b)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
A “controlled corporation” is one in which the beneficiary organization owns 80% of the total combined voting power and at least 80% of the total number of shares of all other classes of stock. <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;368(c)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>“Regularly carried on” for unrelated business income tax purposes, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-6808</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Regularity of activities, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:60</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
Certain activities, such as dances, engaged in intermittently or infrequently (including annually) to raise funds are not considered unrelated businesses.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.513-1(c)(2)(ii), (iii)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>“Regularly carried on” for unrelated business income tax purposes, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-6808</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Regularity of activities, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:60</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Likewise, the sale of products resulting from the performance of exempt activities does not constitute an unrelated trade or business.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.513-1(d)(4)(ii)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
Returns of unrelated business income (<st>IRS Form 990-T</st>) must be filed by every otherwise exempt organization having gross income of types includable in computing unrelated taxable income in excess of $1000. <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.6012-2(e)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Substantially related trade or business for UBIT purposes, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-6811</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:15</designator>
<name>Taxation of unrelated debt-financed and business lease income</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
All tax-exempt organizations are taxed on income they receive from unrelated business interests.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Unrelated business income, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-6800 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Income, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:59</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Such income is subject to the tax on unrelated business income if derived from controlled corporations.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
See <x>&sect;31:12</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Only the exempt function income and the investment income (interest, dividends, royalties, etc.) of the organization is free of taxes.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &dblsect;511, 512.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
Real estate rentals fall into the nontaxable classification, but personal property rentals are taxable unless they are merely incidental to a real property lease. <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;512(b)(3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Income, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:59</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Dividends, interest, and royalties, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:68</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Other investment income, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:70</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Rents, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:71</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
Any business conducted must be substantially related to the exercise of the organization's exempt function in order to avoid taxation. A business in which goods are sold or services are given is classed as an unrelated business.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;513(c)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Unrelated trade or business defined, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-6800 to D-6804</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Income, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:59</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Exceptions exists for (1) businesses where the work is performed by volunteers; (2) businesses primarily for the convenience of students or employees; and (3) businesses consisting of the sale of merchandise received as gifts or contributions.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;513(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Unrelated trade or business defined, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-6800 to D-6804</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Income, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:59</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
The definition of unrelated business income also includes income earned from debt-financed property. The nature of the income is unimportant, whether it takes the form of rents, dividends, royalties, or some other form.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;512(b)(4)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Unrelated debt-financed income, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-7000 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Debt-financed acquisitions, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:77, 10:78</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The purpose is to prevent an exempt organization from buying property on credit and paying for it out of future, untaxed income.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
The income taxed is based on the ratio of the average acquisition debt on the property to the adjusted basis of the property in the hands of the organization.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;514(c)(7)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> This ratio is applied both to the gross income from the property and its expenses to determine the taxable income. Property purchased subject to a mortgage or bought on an installment basis is always debt-financed property.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.514(b)-1(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
Some acquisitions are exempt from this rule. These include purchases of property used in the organization's exempt function (including land near the organization's other property), annuities, low and moderate income housing, and property used in a business related to the exempt activities.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;514(c)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Unrelated debt-financed income, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-7000 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Debt-financed acquisitions, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:77, 10:78</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Special rules apply to acquisitions by an exempt educational institution.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>10</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;514(c)(9)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
Exempt organizations are permitted to engage in certain limited leaseback operations where no more than 25% of the floor space is leased back to the seller and the lease is on commercially reasonable terms.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>11</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;514(c)(9)(G)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Leasebacks covering no more than 25% of leasable space, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-7055.1</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> These activities will not fall under the unrelated business income strictures.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
In addition, certain Code restrictions on the purchase of property have been relaxed. The Code provides that a fixed price and certain participating loan restrictions must be met for a purchase not to be classed as debt-financed.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>12</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;514(c)(9)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> These will no longer apply to property acquired from financial institutions in a qualified purchase. To qualify, the exempt organization must buy the real property from a financial institution that acquired it through foreclosure. Any gain to the financial institution must be ordinary income, the amount of the seller financing cannot exceed the institution's outstanding indebtedness on the property, and the value of the maximum amount payable under any participation feature cannot exceed 30% of the total purchase price.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>13</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;514(c)(9)(H)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:16</designator>
<name>Exemption from state taxation</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
A not-for-profit corporation is exempt from state franchise taxes, except as to any unrelated business tax income of the organization,
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
As to state and federal taxation of unrelated business taxable income, generally, see <x>&dblsect;31:13</x>, <x>31:14</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Corporations not subject to franchise tax, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Taxation and Assessment &sect;1311</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> if the corporation does not have any stock or shares or other certificates of ownership interests, the corporation is operated on a not-for-profit basis, and no part of the corporation's net earnings inure to the benefit of any officer, director, or member.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16" date.trace="1">
<para.text>
<st>20 NYCRR &sect;1-.(b)(6)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16" date.trace="1">
<para.text>
To obtain an exemption, the corporation must file New York Taxation and Finance Form CT-247 and all IRS documents granting or denying an exemption with the Department of Taxation and Finance. The IRS determination is generally followed. <st>20 NYCRR &sect;1-.(b)(6)</st>. While the income to a charitable organization is exempt from state franchise taxation, a return must nonetheless be filed with the Department of Taxation and Finance, generally, on Form CT-3. <st>20 NYCRR &sect;6-1.1</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Not-for-profit corporations are also exempt from the New York City franchise tax to the extent their activities do not generate a profit.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
<cc>Pan American Athletic &amp; Social Club, Inc. v. Commissioner of Finance of City of New York, 94 A.D.2d 606, 461 N.Y.S.2d 1017 (1st Dep't 1983).</cc>
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
All property owned
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
Ownership of the property must rest in the charitable institution to qualify for exemption. <st>RPTL &sect;420-a</st>; <cc>Youth Bldg. Corp. v. Board of Assessors of Nassau County, 56 N.Y.2d 765, 452 N.Y.S.2d 18, 437 N.E.2d 277 (1982)</cc>.
</para.text>
</para>

</footnote.body>
</footnote> by a charitable organization and that is actually and exclusively used to further the organization's charitable purpose is exempt from ad valorem property taxation.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
There are additional exemptions for properties used for specific charitable, religious, educational, medical, and other purposes of benefit to the general public in <st>Article 4 of the Tax Law</st> and in the Education Law.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>What constitutes church, religious society, or institution exempt from property tax under state constitutional or statutory provisions, 28 A.L.R.4th 344</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Property tax: exemption of property leased by and used for purposes of otherwise tax-exempt body, 55 A.L.R.3d 430</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Comment Note: Availability of tax exemption to property held on lease from exempt owner, 54 A.L.R.3d 402</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Prospective use for tax-exempt purposes as entitling property to tax exemption, 54 A.L.R.3d 9</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Requirements for taxation of nonprofit corporation property, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Taxation and Assessment &dblsect;183 to 187</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> To be entitled to an exemption, the corporation must be organized or conducted exclusively for charitable purposes,
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
<cc>Youth Bldg. Corp. v. Board of Assessors of Nassau County, 56 N.Y.2d 765, 452 N.Y.S.2d 18, 437 N.E.2d 277 (1982).</cc>
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Organized for exempt purposes, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Taxation and Assessment &sect;184</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> the property must be devoted exclusively to charitable purposes,
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<cc>User's Query</cc>:
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
 <cc>Delancey Street Foundation, Inc. v. Board of Assessment Review and Assessors of Town of Southeast, 112 A.D.2d 132, 491 N.Y.S.2d 381 (2d Dep't 1985) (criticized on other grounds by </cc><cc>Dynamite Youth Center Foundation Inc. v. Assessor of Town of Fallsburg, Sullivan County, 207 A.D.2d 34, 620 N.Y.S.2d 566 (3d Dep't 1994))</cc>; <cc>Syracuse University v. City of Syracuse, 92 A.D.2d 46, 459 N.Y.S.2d 645, 9 Ed. Law Rep. 1015 (4th Dep't 1983)</cc>; <cc>Zen Center of Syracuse, Inc. v. Gamage, 94 A.D.3d 1490, 943 N.Y.S.2d 346 (4th Dep't 2012)</cc>; see also <trace>Sisters of the Presentation of the Blessed Virgin Mary v. Van Wagenen, 223 A.D.3d 987, 202 N.Y.S.3d 814, 425 Ed. Law Rep. 950 (3d Dep't 2024), appeal dismissed, 41 N.Y.3d 990, 211 N.Y.S.3d 262, 234 N.E.3d 1054 (2024); </trace><cc>Brookdale Physicians' Dialysis Associates, Inc. v. Department of Finance of City of New York, 41 N.Y.3d 608, 215 N.Y.S.3d 51, 239 N.E.3d 157 (2024)</cc><trace>;</trace> <cc>Crouse Health System, Inc. v. City of Syracuse, 126 A.D.3d 1336, 8 N.Y.S.3d 502 (4th Dep't 2015) (the test of entitlement to tax exemption under the used exclusively clause of the Real Property Tax Law is whether the particular use is reasonably incidental to the primary or major purpose of the corporation; put differently, the determination of whether the property is used exclusively for the statutory purposes depends upon whether its primary use is in furtherance of the permitted purposes)</cc>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Used for exempt purposes, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Taxation and Assessment &dblsect;185, 186</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> and the property must be in actual use by the institution in carrying out its charitable purposes.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
<cc>Henry Street Settlement v. Town of Yorktown, 93 A.D.2d 855, 461 N.Y.S.2d 355 (2d Dep't 1983)</cc>; <cc>Welch v. City of Utica, 107 Misc. 2d 745, 435 N.Y.S.2d 892 (Sup 1981)</cc>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Prospective use for tax-exempt purposes as entitling property to tax exemption, 54 A.L.R.3d 9</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Prospective use for exempt purposes, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Taxation and Assessment &sect;186</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
Not-for-profit corporations that meet statutory or regulatory requirements also are specifically exempted from having to pay New York State sales or use taxes.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
<st>NYTL &dblsect;1116, 1210, 1212-A, 1218.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
See <st>NYTL &sect;1116(a)(4)</st>; <st>20 NYCRR &sect;529.7</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Exemption of charitable or educational organization from sales or use tax, 69 A.L.R.5th 477</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Exemption of religious organization from sales or use tax, 54 A.L.R.3d 1204</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Prospective use for tax-exempt purposes as entitling property to tax exemption, 54 A.L.R.3d 9</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Sales and use tax exemption of religious, charitable, and educational organizations, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Taxation and Assessment &dblsect;1838, 1839</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The corporation is also exempt from the New York City vault tax,1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>10</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
<st>New York City Administrative Code &sect;11-2703(4)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> commercial rent tax,1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>11</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
<st>New York City Administrative Code &sect;11-704(a)(4)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> vehicle owner's tax,1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>12</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
<st>New York City Administrative Code &sect;11-2203(6)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> hotel room occupancy tax,1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>13</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
<st>New York City Administrative Code &sect;11-2502(e)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> retail liquor licensee tax,1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>14</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
<st>New York City Administrative Code &sect;11-2403(d)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> taxicab license transfer tax,1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>15</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
<st>New York City Administrative Code &sect;11-1405(a)(4)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> and utility tax.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>16</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
<st>NYTL &sect;1230(d)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
A contributor or a donor of property to a corporation organized for charitable purposes is entitled to a deduction from New York's income1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>17</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
 <st>NYTL &sect;612(a) (the taxpayer's taxable income for state purposes does not include amounts deducted for charitable donations for federal purposes)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> and estate taxes.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>18</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|16|31:16">
<para.text>
<st>NYTL &sect;954</st> (the taxpayer's taxable estate for state purposes does not include amounts deducted for charitable donations for federal purposes).
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
</section.block>
</analytical.level>
<analytical.level>
<front>
<outline.name.block>
<designator>2</designator>
<name> Charity's Status as Private Foundation</name>
</outline.name.block>
</front>
<analytical.level.body>
<section.block>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:17</designator>
<name>Definitions<sep/> Private operating foundation; qualifying distributions; minimum investment return</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
A charitable organization that acts as a private foundation
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
For a discussion of the characteristics that make a charitable organization a private foundation, see <x>&sect;31:3</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private foundations, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-7200 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private foundations, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:100 to 10:118</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> is exempt from taxes on its net investment income and on its undistributed income
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
For a discussion of such taxes, see <x>&sect;31:19</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> if it can establish that it is an exempt operating foundation.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &dblsect;4940(d), 4942(a)(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Operating foundations, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-7713 to D-7715</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Operating foundations, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:116</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> A gray area exists between publicly supported organizations and private foundations that is filled by the concept of a private operating foundation. A “private operating foundation” is an exempt organization that is not publicly supported and is therefore a private foundation but does more than merely make grants to others.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Operating foundations, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-7713 to D-7715</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Operating foundations, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:116</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> These are organizations actively engaged in exempt activities. An example would be an organization established to train teachers that actively conducts courses and seminars.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;53.4942(b)-1(d)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
A private operating foundation is one that uses its charitable contributions for activities that it personally conducts, not just for making grants to others. The funds expended for this purpose must be substantially the entire income of the organization or its minimum investment return.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4942(j)(3)</st>. The Code provides that the organization must make distributions directly for the active conduct of the activities constituting the purpose or function for which it is organized.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
Operating foundations, <field>rc.ref.id="I09IFSI"</field>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;<trace>10:116</trace>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
Operating foundations, <field>rc.ref.id="I09L8XE"</field><trace>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA)</trace> &dblpara;D-<trace>7713 to D-7715</trace>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
Two tests must be met to qualify as a private operating foundation. The first is the income test that requires the organization to spend substantially all (85%) of the lesser of its net income or its minimum investment return.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
“Substantially all” is defined in <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;53.4942(b)-1(c)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The second test is actually a set of three tests, at least one of which must be met:
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
(1) Asset test, where substantially more than half of the assets must be devoted to the organization's exempt activities, a functionally related business, or stock of a controlled corporation devoted to those activities;
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
(2) Endowment test, where at least two-thirds of its annual expenditures for active work must equal two-thirds of its minimum investment return; and
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
(3) Support test, where the foundation's support must come from the public and from five or more organizations, none of which donated more than 25% of the support. The organizations must not be controlled by the foundation. No more than half the support can come from investment income.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4942(j)(3)(B)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Operating foundations, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-7713 to D-7715</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Operating foundations, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:116</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
Once those laborious qualifications are met, a private operating foundation may enjoy five benefits not available to nonoperating foundations. First, donors may contribute and deduct up to 50% of their income to the foundation instead of the 30% maximum permitted for contributions to other foundations.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;170(b)(1)(E)</st>. Pooled fund foundations and foundations that distribute corpus are also entitled to the 50% amount even if not operating foundations.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Second, certain “old-line” foundations may avoid the tax on investment income.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>10</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4940(d)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Organizations qualifying as exempt operating foundations for purposes of excise tax on investment income, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-7505</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Operating foundations, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:116</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> These foundations must have been publicly supported for at least 10 years or else qualified on January 1, 1983; at least 75% of the governing body must not be disqualified persons; the governing body must represent the general public; and no officer of the foundation can be a disqualified person. Third, the minimum payout requirements imposed on private foundations do not apply because they have been replaced by the income test requirements discussed above. Fourth, the requirement that a grant from a private foundation must be expended within one year does not apply.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>11</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4942(g)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Fifth, the tax on self-dealing imposed on private foundations does not apply to private operating foundations.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>12</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4942(a)(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
To be exempt from taxation of its net investment income under <st>Section 4940 of the Internal Revenue Code</st>, an operating foundation must also establish that: (1) it has been publicly supported for at least 10 taxable years; (2) at all times during the tax year in question, the governing body of the organization consisted of individuals, at least 75% of whom were not disqualified, and was broadly representative of the general public; and (3) the foundation at no time during the taxable year had an officer who is a disqualified individual.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>13</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4940(d)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
For a discussion of disqualified persons, see <x>&sect;31:18</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Operating foundations, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-7713 to D-7715</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Operating foundations, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:116</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
“Qualifying distributions” are defined as amounts paid to accomplish or to acquire assets used directly in carrying out one or more charitable purposes other than contributions to: (1) organizations controlled by the foundation or by one or more “disqualified persons”;1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>14</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
For the definition of “disqualified persons,” see <x>&sect;31:18</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Qualified distributions, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-7706 to D-7710</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Distribution of income, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:111, 10:111</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> or (2) to private nonoperating foundations unless such organizations or foundations make qualifying distributions to recipients other than nonoperating foundations in an amount equal to the contribution received within one year of the receipt thereof.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>15</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4942(g)(1), (3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
The minimum investment return for any private foundation for any taxable year is 5% of the excess of: (1) the aggregate fair market value of all assets of the foundation, other than those which are used (or held for use) directly in carrying out the foundation's exempt purpose over (2) the acquisition indebtedness with respect to such assets.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>16</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|17|31:17">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4942(e)(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
</research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Taxes ; Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) p D -7700 toD-7702.
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:18</designator>
<name>Definitions<sep/> Disqualified person; substantial contributor</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|18|31:18">
<para.text>
A “disqualified person” is defined by statute
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|18|31:18">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4946(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|18|31:18">
<para.text>
There is a separate definition of “disqualified individual” for purposes of the tax on income of a foundation, which includes only substantial contributors and owners of the foundation as described below. See <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4940(d)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Disqualified persons defined, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-8101</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Disqualified person transactions, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:108 to 10:110</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> as:
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|18|31:18">
<para.text>
1. A substantial contributor to the foundation.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|18|31:18">
<para.text>
2. A foundation manager.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|18|31:18">
<para.text>
3. An owner of more than 20% of: (a) the voting power of a corporation; (b) the profits interest of a partnership; or (c) the beneficial interest of a trust or unincorporated enterprise, which is a substantial contributor to the foundation.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|18|31:18">
<para.text>
4. A member of the family of any individual described in 1 to 3 above.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|18|31:18">
<para.text>
5. A corporation in which persons described in 1 to 4, above, own more than 35% of the voting power.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|18|31:18">
<para.text>
6. A partnership in which persons described in 1 to 4, above, own more than 35% of the profit interest.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|18|31:18">
<para.text>
7. A trust or estate in which persons described in 1 to 4, above, hold more than 35% of the beneficial interest.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|18|31:18">
<para.text>
8. For purposes of the tax on excess business holdings only,
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|18|31:18">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4943</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Disqualified persons defined, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-8101</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Disqualified person transactions, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:108 to 10:110</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> a private foundation that is effectively controlled by the same persons who control the private foundation in question or a private foundation deriving substantially all of its contributions from the same persons who made substantially all of the contributions to the foundation in question.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|18|31:18">
<para.text>
9. For purposes of the tax on self-dealing only,
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|18|31:18">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4941</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Government officials as limited disqualified persons, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-8103</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Disqualified person transactions, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:108 to 10:110</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> a government official.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|18|31:18">
<para.text>
A “substantial contributor” means any person contributing or bequeathing an aggregate amount of more than $5000 to the foundation if such amount is more than 2% of the total contributions and bequests received by the foundation for the taxable year in which the contribution or bequest is received. It also means the creator of a trust.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|18|31:18">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;507(d)(2)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Disqualified persons defined, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-8101</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Disqualified person transactions, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:108 to 10:110</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|18|31:18">
<para.text>
Self-dealing does not include a transaction between a private foundation and a disqualified person where the disqualified person status arises only as a result of the transaction.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|18|31:18">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;53.4941(d)-1(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:19</designator>
<name>Tax consequences of private foundation status</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
Classification as a private foundation has many tax ramifications. The foundation is not exempt from income taxes,
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;508(e)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Taxation of private foundations, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-7201</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> and donations to the foundation are generally not deductible by the donor.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;508(d)</st>. A deduction is permitted in certain circumstances. See <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;170(b)(1)(E)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Deductibility of gifts of private foundation donee, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:133</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
Additionally, private foundations are subject to a variety of special taxes that are not imposed on other exempt organizations.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
Termination tax. A termination tax applies to a private foundation that is guilty of willful action or inaction that is subject to tax under one of the provisions discussed below. Because of the confiscatory nature of the tax, the organization is terminated by the IRS. However, the tax cannot exceed the smaller of all tax benefits received by the organization because of its exempt status or the total value of the assets of the organization.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;507(c)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
For a discussion of the termination of private foundation status, see <x>&sect;31:24</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> If state officials take over the assets for a charitable purpose, the IRS can abate the tax.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.507-9</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Tax on termination of private foundation status, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-7228 to D-7234</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Termination of foundation, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:118</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
The tax can, theoretically, apply to any change in status, including dissolution or a transfer of all assets to another private foundation. The regulations, however, provide methods for avoiding the tax for transfers and liquidations that comply with a charitable use of the assets.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.507-1</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
Self-dealing tax. A tax is imposed on dealings by a disqualified person with a private foundation.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4941(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
For a definition of “disqualified persons,” see <x>&sect;31:18</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Self-dealing taxes, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-7600 to D-7620</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Expenditure penalty, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:113 to 10:115</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The tax is initially 10% of the amount of the transaction but increases to 200% if the transaction is not reversed. The tax also applies to a foundation manager but is limited to 5% (50% on failure to reverse), with a maximum tax of $20,000. Self-dealing includes sales, leases, loans, and other transactions.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4941(d)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
A disqualified person is one who owns more than 20% of the stock, who manages the operation, or who is a substantial contributor to the organization.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>10</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4946(a)</st>. Family members of these persons along with trusts, partnerships, and corporations associated with them are included as disqualified persons.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> A substantial contributor is one who contributes more than $5,000 if that amount is more than 2% of the total contributions. 1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>11</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;507(d)(2)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> If the organization is a trust, the creator of the trust is a substantial contributor even if his or her contribution is less than $5,000. Governmental employees are also included as disqualified persons.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
An exception exists for such actions as making an interest-free loan to the organization or furnishing goods or services used by the foundation for its exempt activities.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>12</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4941(d)(2)(B)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
Undistributed income tax. If a foundation does not distribute a minimum amount to charity each year, nominally 5% of assets, it is subject to an initial 30% tax on income that should have been distributed.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>13</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4942(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Tax on failures to distribute income, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA), Exempt Organizations &dblpara;D-7700 to D-7728</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Distribution of income, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:111, 10:112</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> If the violation is not remedied, the tax rises to 100%. The assets upon which the calculation is made are reduced by any acquisition indebtedness and by the value of assets used to perform the exempt functions of the foundation.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
Excess business holdings tax. A tax of 10% is levied on excess business holdings of a foundation.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>14</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4943(a)(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Tax on excess business holdings, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA), Exempt Organizations &dblpara;D-7800 to D-7826</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Tax on foundation assets, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:104</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> If these are not divested, the tax can increase to 200%.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>15</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4943(b)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Excess business holdings are those of the foundation and its disqualified persons that exceed 20% of a company. When the company is controlled by unrelated persons, the allowable amount increases to 35%. A foundation can hold up to 2% of a company, whatever the holdings of disqualified persons.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
Jeopardy investments tax. A 10% tax is imposed on both a foundation and its manager on any investment that jeopardizes a foundation's exempt purpose.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>16</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4944(a)(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private foundation investments that jeopardize charitable purposes, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA), Exempt Organizations &dblpara;D-7900 to D-7911</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The Code, in effect, imposes its own prudent investor rule on foundation investments. Under the Treasury regulations, an investment will be considered to jeopardize the carrying out of the exempt purposes of a private foundation if it is determined that the foundation managers, in making the investment, have failed to exercise ordinary business care and prudence, under the facts and circumstances prevailing at the time of making the investment, in providing for the long- and short-term financial needs of the foundation to carry out its exempt purposes. In the exercise of the requisite standard of care and prudence, the foundation managers may take into account the expected return (including both income and appreciation of capital), the risks of rising and falling price levels, and the need for diversification within the investment portfolio (for example, with respect to type of security, type of industry, maturity of company, degree of risk, and potential for return). The determination whether the investment of a particular amount jeopardizes the carrying out of the exempt purposes of a foundation shall be made on an investment-by-investment basis, in each case taking into account the foundation's portfolio as a whole.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>17</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;53.4944-1(a)(2)(i)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The tax can rise to 25% on the foundation, with an additional 5% on the manager.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>18</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4944(b)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Assets related to the exempt purpose of the organization are not included as a jeopardy investment even if no income or appreciation is expected.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>19</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4944(c)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> An example is land and building for a church.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
Legislative activities tax. A tax is imposed on expenditures made to influence legislation, to sway the outcome of an election, or to engage in a voter-registration drive.2
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>20</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4945(d), (e)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Tax on expenditures attempting to influence legislation, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-8004, D-8005</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The initial tax is 20%, and this can rise to 100% of the expenditure if it is not reversed.2
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>21</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4945(a), (b)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> A manager is initially taxed 5%, rising to 50%.2
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>22</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4945(a), (b)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
Prohibited grants tax. Certain grants by a foundation are subject to the same tax as that imposed on prohibited legislative activities.2
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>23</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
