<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4945(d)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Tax on prohibited grants, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-8009 to D-8019</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> These include grants made:
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
(1) to an individual for travel or study unless the grant is made on a nondiscriminatory basis;
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
(2) to a private foundation unless the grantor makes sure the foundation uses the grant properly;
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
(3) to an exempt operating foundation (discussed below) that is not subject to the duty to make sure a grant is not properly used; and
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
(4) to anyone for a purpose other than an exempt purpose.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
Under New York law, an entity classified as a private foundation is required to take the acts necessary to avoid excise taxes being imposed on the corporation.2
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>24</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|19|31:19">
<para.text>
<st>N-PCL &sect;406(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Specific Requirements of the not-for-profit corporation law, see <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;71</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> However, there are no state taxes imposed on such transactions.
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:20</designator>
<name>Returns and reporting requirements</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|20|31:20">
<para.text>
Like most charitable organizations, private foundations must file annual returns.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|20|31:20">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6033(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|20|31:20">
<para.text>
The tax on net investment income is returned on <st>IRS Form 990-PF</st>. All other taxes, such as those on self-dealing, undistributed income, and political expenditures, are reported on <st>IRS Form 4720</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|20|31:20">
<para.text>
For a discussion of the return requirements for exempt organizations, generally, see <x>&sect;31:12</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private foundation returns, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;S-2860 to S-2862</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Failure to file annual returns may result in the imposition of penalties.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|20|31:20">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6652(c)(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|20|31:20">
<para.text>
A private foundation is required to include in its annual return the names and addresses of foundation managers and certain additional information concerning contributions and stock holdings, an income statement, a balance sheet, a schedule of securities and other assets held by the foundation at the close of the taxable year, and a schedule of grants and contributions paid or proof for payment during the taxable year.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|20|31:20">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6033(c)(1)</st>; <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.6033-3</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private foundation returns, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;S-2860 to S-2862</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|20|31:20">
<para.text>
It is further required that all foundations subject to the reporting requirements publish a notice as to the availability for inspection of their annual return within a statutorily specified period from the date of publication.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|20|31:20">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6104(d)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|20|31:20">
<para.text>
A copy of the notice and proof of its publication must be filed with the foundation's return. <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6033(c)(2)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Annual reporting by not-for-profit organizations, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;378</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Annual reporting by charitable organizations, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Charities &sect;87</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Annual financial or other reports, <rc>Am. Jur. 2d, Corporations &sect;278</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Failure to meet the public inspection requirements may result in the imposition of penalties.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|20|31:20">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6652</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Foundation managers are additionally required to furnish copies of the annual return to such state officials at such times and under such conditions as regulations require.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|20|31:20">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6033(c)(2)</st>; <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.6033-3</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Annual reporting by not-for-profit organizations, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;378</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Annual reporting by charitable organizations, <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Charities &sect;87</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Annual financial or other reports, <rc>Am. Jur. 2d, Corporations &sect;278</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:21</designator>
<name>Qualifying for exemption from the foundation rules</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|21|31:21">
<para.text>
Private foundations include all charitable organizations, other than those exempted by statute.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|21|31:21">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;509(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|21|31:21">
<para.text>
For a definition of charitable organizations, see <x>&sect;31:2</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|21|31:21">
<para.text>
For a list of exempt organizations, see <x>&sect;31:3</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Presumption that exempt organization is private foundation, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-7200</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> In determining whether to grant exemption from private foundation status under <st>Sections 509(a)(1)</st> or <st>509(a)(2)</st>, the basic consideration is whether the organization's structure, proposed programs or activities, and intended method of operation are such as to attract the type of broadly based support from the general public, public charities, and governmental units necessary to meet the organization's support requirements.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|21|31:21">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.509(a)-3(d)(2)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|21|31:21">
<para.text>
The support requirements concern mainly the sources of the organization's financing. <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;509(d)</st>. The factors used in determining whether an organization is exempt under <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;509(a)(1)</st> as a “Section 170(b)(1)(A)(vi) organization” are set out in <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.170A-9(f)</st>. The factors in determining whether an organization is exempt under <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;509(a)(2)</st> are set out in <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.509(a)-3</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Churches, schools, hospitals, etc., government-supported charities, and governmental units, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-7203</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Broadly supported organizations, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-7204 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private foundations defined, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:101</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|21|31:21">
<para.text>
In addition to the sources of the organization's financing, pertinent factors in determining the character of the organization include:
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|21|31:21">
<para.text>
Some different factors may be pertinent when an organization seeks to show that it is exempt under <st>Section 170(b)(1)(A)(vi)</st> and thus comes within <st>Section 509(a)(1)</st>, and when an organization seeks to establish exemption under <st>Section 509(a)(2)</st>. See <st>26 C.F.R. &dblsect;1.170A-9(f), 1.509(a)-3(d)(3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Churches, schools, hospitals, etc., government supported charities and governmental units, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-7203</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Broadly supported organizations, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-7204 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private foundations defined, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:101</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|21|31:21">
<para.text>
(1) whether the organization has or will have a governing body comprised of public officials, persons chosen by public officials, community leaders, or persons having special knowledge of a particular relevant field;
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|21|31:21">
<para.text>
(2) whether a substantial portion of the initial funding is to be provided by the general public, public charities, or government grants;
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|21|31:21">
<para.text>
(3) in the case of an organization that carries on fundraising activities, whether concrete plans have been made for solicitation of funds from the general public, whether any steps have been taken to implement such plan, whether any firm commitments have been obtained from exempt charities, and whether the organization has made any commitments to or established any working relationship with those organizations or classes of persons intended as future recipients; and
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|21|31:21">
<para.text>
(4) whether the organization is or will be required to make its services, facilities, performances, or products available to the general public on a continuing basis.
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:22</designator>
<name>Application for exemption from the foundation rules</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|22|31:22">
<para.text>
To be exempt from treatment as a private foundation, a charitable organization generally must notify the IRS within certain time limits that it is applying for recognition as a charitable organization.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|22|31:22">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;508(a)</st>; <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.508-1(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Exempt organization status, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-7200</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|22|31:22">
<para.text>
This notice is normally given by filing <st>IRS Form 1023</st> or <st>1024</st> (depending on the nature of the organization) within 15 months after the end of the month in which the organization was founded.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|22|31:22">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.508-1(a)(2)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|22|31:22">
<para.text>
For a discussion of filing an application, see <x>&sect;31:11</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|22|31:22">
<para.text>
Churches and associated organizations, organizations that are not private foundations and have normal gross receipts of $5000 or less, certain subordinate organizations, and other classes of organizations that the IRS determines should be excluded from the notice requirement need not file this notice but may, nevertheless, file to obtain a favorable ruling.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|22|31:22">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;508(c)</st>; <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.508-1(a)(3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:23</designator>
<name>Exemption from income taxation; contents of foundation's governing instrument</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|23|31:23">
<para.text>
To qualify for exemption from income taxation, private foundations must include limiting provisions in their governing instruments that the organization must distribute its income in each taxable year so as to avoid any tax under <st>Internal Revenue Code Section 4942</st> and that the foundation is prohibited from operating in such manner as to incur tax liability under <st>Internal Revenue Code Section 4941(d)</st> (relating to self-dealing), <st>Internal Revenue Code Section 4943(c)</st> (relating to excess business holdings), <st>Internal Revenue Code Section 4944</st> (relating to investments which jeopardize charitable purpose), or <st>Internal Revenue Code Section 4945</st> (relating to political expenditures).
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|23|31:23">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;508(e)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Provisions required in governing instruments of private foundations, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-7219</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Mandatory governing provisions for private foundations, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:103</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|23|31:23">
<para.text>
The regulations provide that a foundation's governing instrument will be deemed to contain these limitations if a valid state law requires the foundation to operate within these limitations.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|23|31:23">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.508-3(d)(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Such a law has been passed in New York.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|23|31:23">
<para.text>
<st>N-PCL &sect;406</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Specific requirements of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, see <rc>N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;71</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> To avoid any difficulties that might arise in the event of the repeal or invalidation of the statute, it is recommended that the governing instruments of all private foundations contain provisions conforming to Internal Revenue Code requirements, thus insuring the exempt status of the organization. However, any private foundation taking advantage of such a state statute must include in its annual return
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|23|31:23">
<para.text>
 IRS Form 990-PF or IRS Form 4720, filed pursuant to <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6033(a)</st>, see <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.6033-2</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> a statement that it has not taken any action that would exclude it from the coverage of the statute.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|23|31:23">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.508-3(d)(4)(i)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:24</designator>
<name>Termination of private foundation status</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4063</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|24|31:24">
<para.text>
The Internal Revenue Service may terminate an organization's status as a private foundation only if the organization has willfully and flagrantly committed or willfully repeated actions giving rise to penalty excise taxes.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|24|31:24">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;507(a)(2)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Involuntary termination of private foundation status, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-7222</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Termination of foundation, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:118</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> An organization may elect to terminate the private foundation status by giving notice to the Internal Revenue Service
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|24|31:24">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;507(a)(1), (b)(1)(B)(ii)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Voluntary termination of private foundation status, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-7220, D-7221</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Termination of foundation, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:118</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> of its intent to do so.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|24|31:24">
<para.text>
On voluntary termination, the private foundation must file with the Internal Revenue Service a final return consisting of <st>IRS Form 990-PF</st>, if incorporated, a conformed copy of the resolution to dissolve and a certificate of dissolution issued by a court, and a list of organizations to which assets were distributed. All of the above must be signed by an officer of the foundation. In any event, the organization will be subject to a termination tax, unless the tax is abated.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|24|31:24">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;507(a), (g)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Notification of voluntary termination of private foundation status, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-7221</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Tax on termination of private foundation status, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-7228 to D-7234</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Termination of foundation, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:118</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|24|31:24">
<para.text>
The termination tax is equal to the lesser of the aggregate tax benefit, realized by the organization over the period during which it held exempt status, or the value of the foundation's net assets.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|24|31:24">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;507(c)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Tax on termination of private foundation status, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-7228 to D-7234</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Termination of foundation, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:118</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|24|31:24">
<para.text>
With respect to involuntary termination, the tax may be abated under certain circumstances.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|24|31:24">
<para.text>
See <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;507(a)(2), (g)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Abatement of tax on termination of private foundation status, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-7234</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Termination of foundation, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:118</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> With respect to voluntary termination, the tax will be abated if the organization either distributes all of its net assets to one or more publicly supported charitable organizations, which are not private foundations and which have been in continued existence for at least five years, or notifies the Internal Revenue Service that it intends to terminate its private foundation status by altering its organizational and operational structure so as to conform to the requirements for exemption for that status over a continuous five-year period.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|24|31:24">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;507(b)(1)(B)(i), (ii)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|24|31:24">
<para.text>
For discussion of the organizational and operational requirements for exemption from private foundation status, see <x>&sect;31:9</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Abatement of tax on termination of private foundation status, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-7234</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Termination of foundation, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:118</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> This notice must include:
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|24|31:24">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.507-2(b)(3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Abatement of tax on termination of private foundation status, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-7234</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Termination of foundation, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:118</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|24|31:24">
<para.text>
(1) the name and address of the private foundation;
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|24|31:24">
<para.text>
(2) its intention to terminate its private foundation status;
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|24|31:24">
<para.text>
(3) the Code section under which it seeks classification (Section 509(a)(1) to (3));
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|24|31:24">
<para.text>
(4) if Section 509(a)(1) is applicable, the clause of Section 170(b)(1)(A) involved;
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|24|31:24">
<para.text>
(5) the date its regular taxable year begins; and
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|24|31:24">
<para.text>
(6) the date of commencement of the five-year period.
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
</section.block>
</analytical.level>
</analytical.level.body>
</analytical.level>
</analytical.level.body>
</analytical.level>
<analytical.level>
<front>
<outline.name.block>
<designator>II</designator>
<name>Checklists</name>
</outline.name.block>
</front>
<analytical.level.body>
<section.block>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:9</designator>
<name>In general</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
Qualification for tax-exempt status under federal law is conditioned on the applicant's falling precisely within the terms of the statutory exemption in Section 501(c)(3)
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> of the Code.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
<cc>Sun-Herald Corporation v. Duggan, 73 F.2d 298 (C.C.A. 2d Cir. 1934)</cc>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
An organization operated for the primary purpose of carrying on a trade or business for profit is not exempt from taxation on the ground that all of its profits are payable to one or more organizations that are exempt from taxation. The term “trade or business” does not, however, include: (1) the deriving of rents from real property (and personal property leased with it), with certain exceptions; (2) any trade or business in which substantially all the work in carrying it on is performed for the organization without compensation; or (3) any trade or business which is the selling of merchandise, substantially all of which has been received by the organization as gifts or contributions. <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;502</st>. In determining the primary purpose of an organization, all of the circumstances must be considered, including the size and extent of the trade or business and the size and extent of those activities of such organization that are specified in the exemption statute. <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.502-1(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
 For a definition of organizations that qualify under <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(3)</st>, see <x>&sect;31:1</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>For discussion of exempt organizations, generally, see <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-4000 et seq., and Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:53 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
For federal income tax purposes, associations are generally treated as corporations as long as they possess sufficient corporate characteristics, such as limited liability, centralized management, free transferability of interests, and continuity of existence.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
See <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;301.7701-1(b)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
Notwithstanding the exemption from federal income taxation, generally, charitable corporations are required to file an annual information return on <st>IRS Form 990</st> and private foundations are required to file an annual information return on <st>IRS Form 990-PF</st>.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6033</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
Failure to file a return where required may result in the imposition of penalties. <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6652</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private foundation returns, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;S-2860 to S-2862</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
Although private foundations are generally exempt from income tax, they are subject to special taxes and to notification and reporting requirements.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
For a discussion of the taxes on private foundations, see <x>&sect;31:19</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
Subject to certain restrictions on contributions of appreciated property and other restrictions, contributions or gifts to exempt charitable organizations are currently deductible in computing federal income,
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;170</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> estate,
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;2055</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> and gift taxes.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;2522</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
The New York Constitution provides that the legislature may, by general law, which cannot be repealed, exempt from taxation the property used exclusively for religious, educational, or charitable purposes and owned by any corporation organized exclusively for one or more of such purposes and not operating for profit.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
<st>N.Y. Const. Art. XVI, &sect;1</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|9|31:9">
<para.text>
For a discussion of this exemption, see <x>&sect;31:16</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Exemption from real-property taxation of residential facilities maintained by hospital for patients, staff, or others, 61 A.L.R.4th 1105</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Tax exemption of property of educational body as extending to property used by personnel as living quarters, 55 A.L.R.3d 485</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Taxation: exemption of parsonage or residence of minister, priest, rabbi, or other church personnel, 55 A.L.R.3d 356</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Prospective use for tax-exempt purposes as entitling property to tax exemption, 54 A.L.R.3d 9</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Receipt of pay from beneficiaries as affecting tax exemption of charitable institutions, 37 A.L.R.3d 1191</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Homes for the aged as exempt from property taxation, 37 A.L.R.3d 565</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:10</designator>
<name>Qualification for exemption from federal income taxation</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
To qualify for exemption from federal income taxation, an organization must establish that its purpose falls within one of the statutory categories
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Tax-exempt organizations, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:53 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> and that its activities demonstrably serve and are in harmony with the public interest.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<cc>Bob Jones University v. U.S., 461 U.S. 574, 103 S. Ct. 2017, 76 L. Ed. 2d 157, 10 Ed. Law Rep. 918 (1983)</cc> (the tax exemption may be denied if an otherwise qualified organization practices racial discrimination); <st>Rev. Rul. 71-447, 1971-2 C.B. 230.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The organization must be both organized and operated exclusively for charitable purposes.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Form of organization, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:54</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Exempt purposes, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:56</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
Organizational test. A charity is considered organized exclusively for one or more charitable purposes only when its articles of organization (certificate of incorporation, certificate of association, etc.) limit the purposes of the organization to one or more charitable purposes and do not expressly empower the organization to engage in substantial activities not in furtherance of its charitable purposes.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)-1(b)(1)(i), (2)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Form of organization, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:54</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> In meeting this test, the organization's purposes, as stated in its articles of organization, may be as broad as, or more specific than, the language contained in <st>Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code</st>, but in no event may they be broader.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)-1(b)(1)(ii), (iv).</st>
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> An organization is not organized exclusively for one or more exempt purposes if its articles expressly empower it to devote more than an insubstantial part of its activities to attempting to influence legislation by propaganda or otherwise or directly or indirectly to participate in or intervene in any political campaign on behalf of or in opposition to any candidate for public office, including the publishing or distributing of statements, or to have objectives and to engage in activities that characterize it as an “action” organization.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)-1(b)(3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Form of organization, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:54</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Exempt purposes, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:56</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
An organization is not organized exclusively for one or more exempt purposes unless its assets are dedicated to an exempt purpose. However, an organization does not meet the organizational test if, upon dissolution, its articles or the law of the state in which it was created provides that its assets would be distributed to its members or shareholders.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)-1(b)(4)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Form of organization, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:54</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<feature.para.block>
<name.block>
<name>Practice Tips:</name>
</name.block>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
To avoid any problem in obtaining the exemption, it is strongly recommended that the certificate of incorporation of all corporations seeking an exemption contain an express provision irrevocably dedicating the corporation's assets to charitable use and requiring that the assets be distributed to a corporation that will continue to use them for charitable purposes.
</para.text>
</para>
</feature.para.block>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
In construing the articles of organization, the law of the state of creation is controlling. However, any organization contending that any terms have, under state law, a different meaning from their generally accepted meaning must establish the special meaning by clear and convincing reference to relevant court decisions opinions of the state Attorney General, or to other evidence of applicable state law.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)-1(b)(5)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
Operational test. An organization will be regarded as operated exclusively for charitable purposes when it engages primarily in activities that accomplish one or more of the exempt purposes specified in <st>Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code</st> and if no more than an insubstantial portion of its activities is not in furtherance of such purposes.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)-1(c)(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10" date.trace="1">
<para.text>
An organization is not operated exclusively for one or more exempt purposes if its net earnings inure in whole or in part to the benefit of private shareholders or individuals.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>10</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)1(c)(2)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private inurement, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA)&dblpara;D-4040 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private benefit rules, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:88</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
Formerly, if an exempt organization violated the rules against private benefit, the Service's only option was to revoke its exempt status. There are now intermediate sanctions under Section 4958, which imposes excise taxes if a charitable organization transfers an excess benefit to a disqualified person.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>11</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4958</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Excise taxes on excess benefit transactions, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-6650 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
An “excess benefit transaction” is a transaction in which an economic benefit is provided by an exempt organization to a disqualified person in excess of the consideration received.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>12</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4958(c)(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Excise taxes on excess benefit transactions, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA)&dblpara;D-6650 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> A “disqualified person” is someone who, during the five years preceding the transaction, was in a position to exercise substantial influence over the affairs of the organization. Disqualified persons also include family members and certain entities in which at least 35% of the control or beneficial interest are held by persons described in the preceding sentence.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>13</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4958(f)(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Excise taxes on excess benefit transactions, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-6650 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
Initially, the person receiving the benefit must pay a tax of 25% of the amount of the excess benefit.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>14</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4958(a)(1)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> If not corrected within the prescribed period, the person must then pay a tax of 200% of the excess benefit.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>15</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4958(b)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> In addition, an organization manager who knowingly participates in the excess benefit transaction must pay a tax of 10% of the excess benefit.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>16</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4958(a)(2)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The maximum amount of this final tax is limited to $20,000.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>17</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4958(d)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Persons liable for these taxes must file a Form 4720.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>18</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
See <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;53.6011-1(b)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Excise taxes on excess benefit transactions, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-6650 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
Furthermore, “action” organizations, including organizations that have as a substantial part of their activities an attempt to influence legislation by propaganda or otherwise, organizations which participate or intervene, directly or indirectly, in any political campaign on behalf of or in opposition to any candidate for a public office if their main or primary objective or objectives may be attained only by legislation or a defeat of proposed legislation and if they advocate or campaign for the attainment of such main or primary objective or objectives as distinguished from engaging in nonpartisan analysis, study, or research, are not operated exclusively for exempt purposes within the meaning of <st>Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code</st>.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>19</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)-1(c)(3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Political activities, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:92</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> However, such an action organization may, nevertheless, qualify as a social welfare organization under Section 501(c)(4) if it meets the requirements therein.2
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>20</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
See <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(4)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
Additionally, in the case of an organization operated for the primary purpose of carrying on a trade or business for profit, exemption is not allowed under <st>Section 501 of the Internal Revenue Code</st> on the ground that all the profits of such organization are payable to one or more organizations exempt from taxation.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>21</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|10|31:10">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;502</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private inurement, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-4040 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private benefit rules, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:88</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:11</designator>
<name>Application for exemption from federal income taxation</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
A new charitable organization is not treated as exempt under Section 501(c)(3) unless and until it gives the IRS notice that it is applying for recognition of its exempt status.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;508(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Exempt organization status, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-7200</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The notice requirements do not apply to churches, to associations of churches, or to organizations (other than private foundations) with gross receipts not in excess of $5000.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;508(c)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>For a discussion of the application by a charitable organization for determination of exempt status, see <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA)&dblpara;D-4000 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><rc>Liability of Nonprofit Corporation for Engaging in For-Profit Business Activities, 46 Am. Jur. Proof of Facts 3d 431</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11" date.trace="1">
<para.text>
Notice is generally given by filing <st>IRS Form 1023 </st> within 15 months after the end of the month in which the organization was organized.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
 <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.508-1(a)(2)(i) (also providing that any requests for extension of time for the filing of such notice be submitted to the ).</st>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
See also <cc>National Paralegal Inst. Coalition v. C.I.R., T.C. Memo. 2005-293, T.C.M. (RIA) P 2005-293 (2005)</cc>, where the Service reviews procedural aspects of filing Form 1023.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Application by a charitable organization for determination of exempt status, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-4000 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Application for exempt status, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:57</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
Any organization excepted from the requirement of filing notice under Section 508(a) will be exempt from taxation under Section 501(c)(3) if it meets the requirements of that section, whether or not it files such notice. However, in order to establish the exemption with the Internal Revenue Service and receive a ruling or determination letter recognizing its exempt status, an organization excepted from the notice requirement should file proof of its exemption.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.508-1(a)(4)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
Along with <st>IRS Form 1023</st>, the applicant must submit certain documents establishing conformity with organizational and operational requirements.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
For discussion of organizational and operational requirements for exemption, see <x>&sect;31:9</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
For a checklist of the documents that should accompany the application, see <x>&sect;31:28</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
When an organization has established its exempt status, the IRS will issue a ruling or determination letter. Such a ruling or determination letter may be issued in advance of operations if the organization can describe its proposed operations in sufficient detail to permit a conclusion that it will clearly meet the particular requirements of the section of law under which exemption is claimed.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
<st>I.R.S. Pub. 557.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Normally, such a determination is effective as of the date the organization was formed. However, if an organization is required to alter its activities or substantially amend its charter to qualify, the ruling or determination letter is effective as of the date specified in the letter.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
<st>I.R.S. Pub. 557</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> If a nonsubstantial amendment is made, such as correction of a clerical error in the enabling instrument or the addition of a dissolution clause, exemption is usually recognized as of the date of formation if the organization's activities before the ruling or determination are consistent with the exemption requirements.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
<st>I.R.S. Pub. 557.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Upon obtaining recognition of exemption, the organization may file a claim for a refund of income taxes paid for the period for which its exempt status is recognized.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>10</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
<st>I.R.S. Pub. 557.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
Rulings and determination letters granting exemptions may be revoked. The revocation may be retroactive if the organization omitted or misstated a material fact, operated in a manner materially different from that originally represented, or engaged in a prohibited transaction.1
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>11</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|11|31:11">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;601.201(n)(6)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Continuity of exemption, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-4002</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:12</designator>
<name>Effect of exempt status; returns</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
Unless it is also classified as a private foundation,
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
See <st>26 U.S.C.A. &dblsect;4940 et seq.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
For definition of private foundation, see <x>&sect;31:3</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> an organization that establishes its status as a charity is exempt from income tax, except with respect to unrelated business income.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
<st>NYTL &dblsect;290 et seq.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
As to taxation of unrelated business income, see <x>&sect;31:14</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Notwithstanding this exemption, most charities are required to file federal annual information returns.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6033</st> (<st>IRS Form 990</st>).
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
For exceptions to filing, see <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6033(a)(3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Private foundation returns, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;S-2860 to S-2862</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Failure to file these returns may result in the imposition of penalties.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
See <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6652</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
The Code requires an exempt organization to allow public inspection of its application for exemption and its three most recent annual information returns. The exempt organization must furnish copies of these documents on request. The copies must be provided without charge, other than for the reasonable costs of copying and mailing.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
See <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6104(d)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Disclosure requirements, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:58</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
Private foundations also are required to allow public inspection of the entities' tax returns.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|12|31:12">
<para.text>
See <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6104(d)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:13</designator>
<name>Tax differences among exempt organizations</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
The tax treatment of an exempt organization depends on the specific requirements imposed on the organization and which of the three basic classifications in which it is placed. Exempt organizations are initially divided between public charities and private foundations. Public charities include hospitals, schools, and churches. Private foundations are then divided between operating foundations and nonoperating foundations. In addition to these fundamental differences, the tax code imposes specific requirements on specific exempt entities. For example, a social club must not discriminate in membership qualifications on the basis of race, color, or religion in order to remain exempt.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(i)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Discriminatory actions of social clubs, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-6607</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Social and recreational clubs, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:75</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
Four basic categories of difference exist among the three basic forms of exempt organizations. For some purposes, private operating foundations are treated like public charities, while for other purposes they are treated like private foundations.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
Charitable deduction limitations. The limit on contributions to a public charity is the maximum amount allowed under the Code, which is 50% of the contributor's adjusted gross income for cash contributions and 30% for property that has appreciated in value.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;170(b)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Qualified donee charitable organizations, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA), &dblpara;K-2850 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Charitable contributions, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:74</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Deductible contributions, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:119 to 10:144</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> The same limitation applies to private operating foundations. For private (nonoperating) foundations, the limit is 30% for both kinds of property. Certain other property is limited to 20% of income and the amount deducted is limited to the donor's basis in the property.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
Permitted activities. Of the three groups, a public charity is granted the most freedom as to its manner of operating. It either may operate its own activities or may make grants to other operating entities. It may also engage in lobbying activities. A private operating foundation must be at least partially engaged in operational activities in order to be a private operating foundation, while a private foundation only makes grants to others. Neither a private foundation nor a private operating foundation may engage in lobbying activities. A private foundation may not make grants in excess of stated amounts to other private foundations.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
Tax on entities. A public charity is not subject to tax on its activities except for a tax levied on the charity's unrelated business income
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;511(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> and a tax on excess lobbying expenditures.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4911(c)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
Taxation of unrelated business income, see <x>&sect;31:14</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
Both private foundations and private operating foundations are subject to a variety of taxes on disqualified transactions and on undistributed income. The tax starts at 2% initially and can then reach 200%. Disqualified activities include such things as self-dealing between the organization and its managers or contributors, excess investments in private corporations, jeopardy investments in general, and similar actions.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &dblsect;4940, 4941</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
For rules on self-dealing see, <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4941(d)</st>. Self-dealing involves certain acts by a disqualified person (see <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;53.4941(d)-1(a)</st>). A disqualified person is defined as a substantial contributor; a foundation manager; a person who owns more than 20% of a corporation, partnership, trust, or unincorporated enterprise which is itself a substantial contributor; and/or a member of the family of any individual of the first three categories. See <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4946(a)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
Distribution requirements. Public charities are not subject to any requirement as to distributions. However, an operating foundation must distribute at least 3 1/3% of the value of its investment assets, while a nonoperating foundation must distribute at least 5% of its assets.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|13|31:13">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4942</st>. An operating foundation need pay only two-thirds of its minimum return rather than the full amount required of a nonoperating foundation.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Tax on failure to distribute income, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-7700 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Distribution of income by private foundations, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:111, 10:112</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:14</designator>
<name>Taxation of unrelated business income</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
Under both state and federal law, charitable organizations are subject to a tax, comparable to an ordinary business tax at corporate rates, on unrelated business income.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;511</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
<st>NYTL &dblsect;290 et seq.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Unrelated business income, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-6800 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Income, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:59</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Dividends, interest, and royalties, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:68</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Other investment income, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:70</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Rents, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:71</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> An unrelated business is one, the conduct of which (aside from the need for funds) is not substantially related to the charitable function of the exempt organization.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;513</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
Exception is made for businesses in which all work is performed without compensation; in which the business is carried out primarily for the convenience of members, officers, employees, students, or patients; or in which the business consists of selling merchandise substantially all of which has been received as gifts or contributions. <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;513(a)(1) to (3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Unrelated trade or business defined, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-6800 to D-6804</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Income, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:59</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Interest, rents, royalties, and annuities received from certain controlled corporations are also subject to the tax on unrelated business income.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;512(b)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
A “controlled corporation” is one in which the beneficiary organization owns 80% of the total combined voting power and at least 80% of the total number of shares of all other classes of stock. <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;368(c)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>“Regularly carried on” for unrelated business income tax purposes, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-6808</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Regularity of activities, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:60</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
Certain activities, such as dances, engaged in intermittently or infrequently (including annually) to raise funds are not considered unrelated businesses.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.513-1(c)(2)(ii), (iii)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>“Regularly carried on” for unrelated business income tax purposes, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-6808</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Regularity of activities, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:60</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Likewise, the sale of products resulting from the performance of exempt activities does not constitute an unrelated trade or business.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
<st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.513-1(d)(4)(ii)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|14|31:14">
<para.text>
Returns of unrelated business income (<st>IRS Form 990-T</st>) must be filed by every otherwise exempt organization having gross income of types includable in computing unrelated taxable income in excess of $1000. <st>26 C.F.R. &sect;1.6012-2(e)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Substantially related trade or business for UBIT purposes, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &para;D-6811</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>31:15</designator>
<name>Taxation of unrelated debt-financed and business lease income</name>
</outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><tk>West's Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 to 4079</tk></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
All tax-exempt organizations are taxed on income they receive from unrelated business interests.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Unrelated business income, <rc>Federal Tax Coordinator 2d (RIA) &dblpara;D-6800 et seq</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Income, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:59</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Such income is subject to the tax on unrelated business income if derived from controlled corporations.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
See <x>&sect;31:12</x>.
</para.text>
</para>
</footnote.body>
</footnote> Only the exempt function income and the investment income (interest, dividends, royalties, etc.) of the organization is free of taxes.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
<st>26 U.S.C.A. &dblsect;511, 512.</st>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
Real estate rentals fall into the nontaxable classification, but personal property rentals are taxable unless they are merely incidental to a real property lease. <st>26 U.S.C.A. &sect;512(b)(3)</st>.
</para.text>
</para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Income, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:59</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Dividends, interest, and royalties, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:68</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Other investment income, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:70</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry date.trace="1"><ref.text>Rents, <rc>Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:71</rc>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</footnote.body>
</footnote>
</para.text>
</para>
<para ct.id="f477b8b0b92511efa86bc22ba615bad8|15|31:15">
<para.text>
Any business conducted must be substantially related to the exercise of the organization's exempt function in order to avoid taxation. A business in which goods are sold or services are given is classed as an unrelated business.
<footnote>
<footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference>
<footnote.body>
